We denote by \zeta ^{(p)}(s) the \zeta function with its Eulerian factor at p removed: \zeta ^{(p)}(s) \coloneqq \sum _{p \nmid n} 1/n^s. We know that the values of \zeta ^{(p)}(s) on the negative integers are rational and admit a p-adic interpolation. More precisely,
Let \mathbb {C} _p be the completion of an algebraic closure of \mathbb {Q} _p. Then the characters \chi \colon \mathbb {Z} _p^ \times \to \mathbb {C} _p^ \times are the points of a rigid analytic space.
There exists exactly one rigid analytic function \zeta _p^{(p)}( \chi ), with a simple pole at \chi =(x \mapsto x^{-1}), such that \zeta _p^{(p)}(x \mapsto x^{-1}) = \zeta ^{(p)}(n) \in \mathbb {Q} for every integer n<0.

We set, for n \in \mathbb {Z} with n \neq1, \zeta _p^{(p)}(n) \coloneqq \zeta _p^{(p)}(x \mapsto x^{-1}). This notation differs from that of [C] or [Ko]: our \zeta _p^{(p)} is not a continuous p-adic function of the integer n. Instead, it is a continuous function of the character x \mapsto x^n, itself a continuous function of n if and only if we restrict n to an arithmetic progression of difference p-1. We have \zeta _p^{(p)}(n) = \lim _a \zeta ^{(p)}(n-(p-1)p^a). The trivial zeros of \zeta force \zeta _p^{(p)}(n)=0 for even n, i.e. for x \mapsto x^{-n} an even character. More generally, \zeta _p^{(p)}( \chi )=0 for even \chi.

With this notation, we have (cf. [C; Ko]) \operatorname {vp} \ell _k^{(p)}(1) = \zeta _p^{(p)}(k) and can be rewritten as
